unnormalised: Hey guys, just wanted to share something about the whole results season that just wrapped up. It's always a crazy time, right? Everyone's stressing about their marks, comparing percentages, and wondering what's next. Remember those sleepless nights studying?
normalised: Hey guys, just wanted to share something about the whole results season that just wrapped up. It's always a crazy time, right? Everyone's stressing about their marks, comparing percentages, and wondering what's next. Remember those sleepless nights studying?

unnormalised: My younger brother, Rohan, just got his Class 10 results. He was so worried! He aimed for 90% plus but was super nervous right before the results came out. He kept saying "What if I only get 70%? What will everyone say?" Classic Rohan!
normalised: My younger brother, Rohan, just got his Class ten results. He was so worried! He aimed for ninety percent plus but was super nervous right before the results came out. He kept saying "What if I only get seventy percent? What will everyone say?" Classic Rohan!

unnormalised: Turns out, he scored a respectable 85% overall! I’m so proud of him. He was initially bummed he didn’t hit his 90%, but I told him it’s still amazing. And frankly, a lot better than what I got way back when! Remember, marks aren't everything. Skill is more important than % marks on a paper.
normalised: Turns out, he scored a respectable eighty five percent overall! I’m so proud of him. He was initially bummed he didn’t hit his ninety percent, but I told him it’s still amazing. And frankly, a lot better than what I got way back when! Remember, marks aren't everything. Skill is more important than percentage marks on a paper.

unnormalised: And speaking of results, I was reminiscing about my own graduation days from DU. My B.Com. final year result was a nail-biter. I needed at least 50% to pass, and I was sweating bullets. Managed to scrape through with 52% in aggregate! Haha! Those were the days.
normalised: And speaking of results, I was reminiscing about my own graduation days from D-U. My B-Com. final year result was a nail-biter. I needed at least fifty percent to pass, and I was sweating bullets. Managed to scrape through with fifty two percent in aggregate! Haha! Those were the days.

unnormalised: What’s funny is, I remember one friend, Aisha, who was always topping the class. She got like 98% in her Class 12 boards from Amity International. Everyone thought she'd become a doctor or engineer. But she ended up opening a bakery!
normalised: What’s funny is, I remember one friend, Aisha, who was always topping the class. She got like ninety eight percent in her Class twelve boards from Amity International. Everyone thought she'd become a doctor or engineer. But she ended up opening a bakery!

unnormalised: It just goes to show you, those academic results, while important at the time, don’t always dictate your future. It's about what you do with what you've learned. Maybe those with 60% are just as capable, if not more so, than those with 90%.
normalised: It just goes to show you, those academic results, while important at the time, don’t always dictate your future. It's about what you do with what you've learned. Maybe those with sixty percent are just as capable, if not more so, than those with ninety percent.

unnormalised: So, to all you students out there who just got your results, whatever they may be, take a deep breath. Don't let a number define you. Celebrate your hard work, learn from your mistakes, and keep moving forward. Focus on skills, not just getting 99/100. There's so much more to life than a report card!
normalised: So, to all you students out there who just got your results, whatever they may be, take a deep breath. Don't let a number define you. Celebrate your hard work, learn from your mistakes, and keep moving forward. Focus on skills, not just getting ninety nine divided by one hundred. There's so much more to life than a report card!

unnormalised: And parents, chill out! Support your kids, no matter what. A kid getting 75 per cent instead of 95 per cent, does not mean he is any less. A little encouragement goes a long way. Okay, rant over! What are your result-day memories? Let me know in the comments!
normalised: And parents, chill out! Support your kids, no matter what. A kid getting seventy five percent instead of ninety five percent, does not mean he is any less. A little encouragement goes a long way. Okay, rant over! What are your result-day memories? Let me know in the comments!
